Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Statistical Tools to Quantify and Mitigate the Spread of COVID-19
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop rigorous statistical models and inference tools to better understand the spread of COVID-19 as well as the type of the interventions that are most likely to work to prevent further outbreak. The work will result in concrete approaches for quantifying uncertainty of possible outcomes and provide reliable tools to assist decision makers in designing mitigation strategies for the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, a new statistical inference tool will be developed to estimate the key epidemic parameters that describe the nature of the COVID-19 spread in an interpretable manner. These parameters are critical for providing reliable forecasts through real-time simulation of potential outbreaks. The new models will analyze the effects of changing social contact structures on the spread of COVID-19, and account for missing or partial data in a systematic way. The results of this project will contribute to the scientific and mathematical approaches needed to provide effective and quick understanding of future epidemics or relevant phenomena.<br/><br/>Existing epidemic models largely rely on deterministic systems that are unable to quantify the uncertainty critical for decision making. In addition, data analysis and predictive modeling for the COVID-19 pandemic require statistical tools for fitting epidemic models with only partially available data. However, most stochastic models face challenges in the face of missing data. To address this gap, the project team will develop new stochastic compartmental models that extend classical approaches to explicitly account for changes to the social contact network underlying the disease spread. These new developments will be accompanied by likelihood-based methods to infer key epidemic parameters that offer mechanistic interpretations with uncertainty quantification. In particular, missing data such as infection times at the individual level will be accounted for via novel data augmentation techniques. The results of this project will provide guidance both to the scientific community on how to evaluate the COVID-19 pandemic, and to the general public on which mitigation strategies would be most effective.<br/><br/>This grant is being awarded using funds made available by the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act supplemental funds allocated to MPS.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of this project were to create statistical models that will evaluate the effects of different contact structures on the progression of epidemics, while accounting for missing data. More specifically, the development of these statistical models will allow us to better understand the spread of COVID-19 and make more informed decisions about the best possible mitigation interventions. Developing statistical methods that also estimate uncertainty in epidemic models will provide additional tools to assist in the process of decision-making and strategizing in emerging pandemics.  The parameters will provide interpretable, reliable, and real-time simulation of potential outbreaks. This work was made possible through both novel and available data collection by the UNC PI site. The UNC site was responsible for developing the study design and deploying the blue tooth sensors in a study of COVID-19 among health care workers.  The sensors provided fine data on interactions and movement within the hospital environment, between study participants, and in areas with COVID-19 patients. Therefore, the main goals of the UNC site project work, focused on the design, implementation, and collection of the sensor data for measuring health care personnel contacts in the hospital setting, in both COVID-19 wards and other areas of the hospital. We collected extensive data on network interactions that demonstrate occupational interaction patterns and time spent in patient zones, to better inform occupational risk.  Overall, the data that were produced as part of this study, will be useful for parameterizing network models and for predicting risk of COVID-19 exposure in the health care setting.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2021
Modified by: Allison Aiello

More specifically, the development of these statistical models will allow us to better understand the spread of COVID-19 and make more informed decisions about the best possible mitigation interventions. Developing statistical methods that also estimate uncertainty in epidemic models will provide additional tools to assist in the process of decision-making and strategizing in emerging pandemics. The parameters will provide interpretable, reliable, and real-time simulation of potential outbreaks. This work was made possible through both novel and available data collection by the UNC PI site. The UNC site was responsible for developing the study design and deploying the blue tooth sensors in a study of COVID-19 among health care workers. The sensors provided fine data on interactions and movement within the hospital environment, between study participants, and in areas with COVID-19 patients. Therefore, the main goals of the UNC site project work, focused on the design, implementation, and collection of the sensor data for measuring health care personnel contacts in the hospital setting, in both COVID-19 wards and other areas of the hospital. We collected extensive data on network interactions that demonstrate occupational interaction patterns and time spent in patient zones, to better inform occupational risk. Overall, the data that were produced as part of this study, will be useful for parameterizing network models and for predicting risk of COVID-19 exposure in the health care setting.
